metadata.title: What is Natural Language Processing? | by Sukanta Saha | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Natural languages are languages that convey ideas through the utilization of written elements. These obviously include languages like English, ancient Greek, Chinese, and Dothraki but do not include…

all_paragraphs: Natural languages are languages that convey ideas through the utilization of written elements. These obviously include languages like English, ancient Greek, Chinese, and Dothraki but do not include Computer languages like Python or R. Ancient languages which use art as a form of expression may be somewhere in the grey area between what is considered Natural language and what is not, in the conventional sense. Any sort of processing like manipulation, curation, or analysis of these Natural languages is considered NLP.

NLP typically involves applications of Computer Science and Linguistics. The very first task we taught computers for NLP was deconstructing the sentence structure into smaller components like the noun phrase or the verb phrase. These are further divided to specifically assign their Parts of Speech tag in the context of the sentence. Hard coding these rules into a program may be a little too tedious, but doable up to a certain level of complexity. Refer to this article to learn how to PoS tag using NLTK.

Computer languages follow strict rules and syntax. Natural languages, however, are more diverse and unconventional. We know how to make sense of the different combinations of words, meanings, accents, word-plays, and speaking styles, taking into account the contextual understanding of a piece of text. It’s probably one of those things we associate the most with being human. But computers could not. Enter Machine Learning.

Modern NLP has been driven by extensive applications of Machine Learning. Much of the recent advancements are enabled by Deep Learning techniques which enable computers to form complex networks of semantics by training on pre-existing text data. Just like we observe others use a certain word in a certain way and then process it in our brain to derive its semantics, Deep Learning to some extent, simulates this experience within the DL model to learn the innate rules and conventions of natural language.

Imagine how you process words in your brain. Words with similar semantics may be represented by neurons that are closer together. Now imagine a 3D graph, with each dimension representing an aspect of the meaning of a word. These aggregate into a vector to represent the cumulative semantics of the word. A machine learning model would put similar words closer together within the sample space, except, not on a graph with just three dimensions, but plausibly many, many more.

Applications of NLP include reading, writing, listening, and speaking natural languages using computers. In 2015, DeepMind published a paper describing how they taught ML models to read texts and then answer comprehension questions based on those texts. Areas like sentiment analysis and engineering chatbots are booming. Many large firms are using internet-wide sentiment analysis programs to estimate public outlook about companies before investing in their stocks, whereas, chatbots are engineered to seem more and more like humans to automate the customer service industry.

Predictive text analysis is a technology we use on a regular basis when we type on our smartphones and use those text suggestions. The keyboards constantly train on our previous behavior, i.e. how we type, which words we use most often, which short forms we use, which words we tend to use together, etc, and predict our text based on probability. In fact, computers are now so good at writing that, we can use them for writing a whole blog post! The following is an article generated by AI from ai-writer.com about “Natural Language Processing”.

Natural Language Processing (NLP) is an area of artificial intelligence that gives machines the ability to read, understand and derive meaning from human language. The concept itself is fascinating, but the real value of this technology lies in the use cases. Simply put, it represents a new type of armament in many industries, particularly data science and artificial intelligence. There are a number of disciplines that focus on the interaction between data science and human languages. [Sources: 3]  NLP can help with many tasks, and the field applications seem to increase daily. One of the most popular methods of using natural language processing is data science and artificial intelligence, as well as data analysis. [Sources: 1, 3]  This branch of computer linguistics can be used, for example, to develop chatbots and digital assistants or to facilitate everyday communication, including through translation. I have no idea how many subjects we can use, but I am sure you do. A corpus of linguistics is a point where the branch of applied linguistics is a collection of assumptions and generalizations that can be made from written data and text-based data (e.g. data analysis). [Sources: 1]  An enormous amount of text can be analyzed and edited with NLP methods, whereby correlations can also be found within a text. Aristo found his answers from billions of documents using artificial intelligence, a branch of computer science (artificial intelligence) that allows computers to extract meaning from unstructured texts. Although we are still a long way from machines that can understand and speak human language, N LP has become an important part of many of the applications we use every day, including chatbots, digital assistants, and even human communication and translation. [Sources: 1, 7]  Replicating language — the processing capacity of the human mind has been a historical pain point for artificial intelligence, but it is subject to the limitations of NLP as a means of reproducing human language. [Sources: 7]  In many cases, language carries hidden meanings that imply how an object relates to another object. Against this background, we should round out our understanding with some other clear — trimmed definitions that can strengthen our ability to explain NLP and its meaning to a broader audience and organization. [Sources: 2, 7]  Natural language processing (NLP) is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) that deals with communication. This broad field is responsible for addressing problems ranging from speech recognition and transcription to text translation between different languages, extracting units (such as people and places) from the text and ensuring a more accurate representation of the language and its meaning in real time. Engineers build N-LP models to teach computers to understand and even replicate the way we communicate. How can a computer be programmed to generate and understand language like a person, and how do we understand it? [Sources: 0, 2]  Originally, the term referred to the ability to read a system, but has now become a slang term for computer linguistics. The sub-categories include creating your own communication and understanding other languages such as language, speech recognition and text — to — language. [Sources: 0]  In this way, words come together like any other form of data, but in a much more natural way than with other forms of processing. [Sources: 0]  NLP combines AI with computer linguistics and computer science to process human natural language and language. The first task of NLP is to understand the natural languages that the computer receives, and further developments in machine learning are possible. [Sources: 5]  The computer uses a built-in — in statistical model to perform speech recognition routines that convert natural language into programming languages and then into a programming language. [Sources: 5]  Natural Language Processing (NLP) is the process of communication with intelligent systems that use natural language such as English. Natural language processing is necessary if we want an intelligent system, like a robot, to execute instructions for us or to hear decisions from a dialogue — based or clinical. [Sources: 6]  Natural Language Processing (NLP) is part of the field of artificial intelligence, which enables computers to analyze and understand human language. This includes using computers with natural language used by humans to perform useful tasks such as speech, speech recognition, and speech communication. Natural language processing, or the process of developing software that generates and understands natural languages so that users have a natural conversation between themselves and their computers, has been formulated to lay the groundwork for the development of intelligent systems with human intelligence. [Sources: 5, 6]  Natural Language Processing (NLP) is an artificial intelligence (AI) branch used to simplify the way the world works. Processing natural language (usually abbreviated N LP) or natural language as a whole is the branch of artificial intelligence that deals with natural languages used by humans, such as language, speech recognition and speech communication. [Sources: 4, 5]  The ultimate goal of NLP is to read, understand and understand human language in a way that is valuable to us. For example, it can be used to check the grammatical correctness of a text, as well as for speech recognition and speech communication. [Sources: 4]

Pretty impressive! Although, not quite there yet. The individual sentences are mostly grammatically accurate and can be comprehended by us. The connection between sentences however is where it needs to improve. The writing does not always flow naturally from one paragraph to the next. The AI seems to only try to define what NLP is. It did try to elaborate on some occasions and move on to different areas of an NLP blog but was not very clear about what it meant. As it stands, this particular model needs to improve on understanding the context of writing a blog post on a higher level such as getting into some more detail of the applications of NLP, or how it works under the hood, or perhaps even featuring a blog generated by AI.

Current innovations include using computer vision in conjunction with NLP to simulate a more complete form of perception. For instance, if we have an image of cats in a cup, that is recognized by computer vision, and we ask for images with cats minus the cup, the AI can return images of just cats. Or if we wanted images of cats minus the cup, plus boxes, the AI can return images of cats inside boxes instead of cups, all without having these pictures manually tagged. This paper from 2015 elaborates on this application.

NLP is also being used to decipher big biological data. With gene sequencing being more and more accessible, scientists have been producing thousands of terabytes of data. From predicting gene functions to protein structures and functions and from predicting drug efficacy for each individual patient based on their genotype to discovering potential compounds for drug development, NLP has been instrumental, to say the least.

The ultimate goal of NLP is to simulate human-like perception, be it by combining computer vision, or speech recognition, or any other clever combination and permutation. With the advent of ML and the increase in computation power through parallel computing, it has been an exciting time for NLP.

The invention of language is probably one of the most important inventions of mankind, according to historian Yuval Noah Harari. In his book Sapiens, he talks about the theory of how language could have played an integral role in our fight against other humans like the Homo neanderthalensis. To be able to give this tool to a man-made machine with all its intricacies would surely be a massive endeavor.
Bonus: Check out this website for some AI-generated dank memes.
P.S. If you want more short, to the point articles on Data Science and how a biologist navigates his way through the Data revolution, consider following my blog.
